overview: Find out about National Insurance - your National Insurance Number, what it's for, how much you pay, how to check your contributions record
title: National Insurance

table.body:
You pay National Insurance contributions to build up your entitlement to certain state benefits, including the State Pension. 

You pay National Insurance if you're:

- 16 or over
- an employee earning above £146 a week  
- self employed making a profit over £5,995 a year

The exact amount you pay depends on:

- how much you earn
- whether you're employed or self-employed

You may also want to pay [voluntary contributions](/voluntary-national-insurance-contributions "Voluntary contributions") to make up for gaps in your National Insurance record. For example, you can have a gap when you weren't working and didn't get any state benefits.  

##When you stop paying

If you're employed, you stop paying Class 1 National Insurance when you reach the [State Pension age.](http://pensions-service.direct.gov.uk/en/state-pension-age-calculator/home.asp "State Pension age"){:rel="external"} 

If you're self-employed you stop paying:

- Class 2 National Insurance contributions when you reach State Pension age
- Class 4 contributions from the start of the tax year after the one in which you reach State Pension age

*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Your National Insurance number makes sure your National Insurance contributions and tax are only recorded against your name. 

It's made up of letters and numbers and never changes. 

^You can apply to [get a National Insurance number](/national-insurance-number "get a National Insurance number") if you don't have one.^

##Who uses your National Insurance number

These organisations need to know what your number is:

- HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)
- your employer
- the Department for Work and Pensions (which includes Jobcentre Plus and the Pension, Disability and Carers Service), if you claim state benefits, or in Northern Ireland the Department for Social Development 
- your local council, if you claim Housing Benefit, or the Northern Ireland Housing Executive
- the Student Loan Company, if you apply for a student loan
- your ISA provider, if you open an ISA

^To prevent identity fraud, keep your National Insurance number safe and don't give it to anyone who doesn't need it.^

*[ISA]:Individual Savings Account

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Your National Insurance number

table.body:
##If you're employed

You pay Class 1 National Insurance contributions. The rates are:

- if you earn between £107 and £146 you're automatically covered for State Pension and benefits
- 12% on your weekly earnings between £146 and £817  
- an extra 2% on any earnings over £817 

You pay National Insurance with your tax. Your employer will take it from your wages before you get paid.

If you’re a director of a limited company, you may also be your own employee and pay National Insurance Class 1 through your PAYE payroll. If your company’s profits are above a certain amount you might also have to pay Class 2 and 4 - see ‘If you’re self-employed’.

##If you're self-employed

You’re responsible for paying your own National Insurance. How much you pay depends on your profits:

Annual profits | Class 2 | Class 4
 - | - | -
up to £5,595 | £0 but only if you [get an exemption](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/forms/view.page?record=yKpjabZqCc8&formid=433 "class 2 exception"){:rel="external"} | £0
£5,595 - £7,604 | £2.65 a week | £0
£7,605 - £42,475 | £2.65 a week | 9% of profits
more than £42,475 | £2.65 a week | 9% of profits up to £42,475 and 2% over that amount

You [pay Class 2](/pay-class-2-national-insurance "pay class 2 national insurance") either via direct debit once a month or every 6 months or you can ask HMRC to bill you twice a year. Your Class 4 contributions will be paid with your Income Tax. You can set up your payments when you [register for Self Assessment](/register-for-self-assessment "register for Self Assessment") or [change how you pay](/pay-class-2-national-insurance "pay class 2 national insurance").

##If you’re employed and self-employed

You might be an employee but also do self-employed work. In this case your employer will take care of your class 1 payments and you have to pay your class 2 and 4 payments like any other self-employed person. How much you pay when [employed and self-employed](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/working/intro/employed-selfemployed.htm "employed and self-employed"){:rel="external"} depends on your combined income from all your jobs.

##If you're a share fisherman
If you're a share fisherman - ie you're employed on a British fishing boat but not under a contract of service - you pay a different rate of Class 2 NICs. In 2012-13 the rate is £3.30 a week. This contributes towards the basic State Pension, the normal range of benefits for self-employed people, plus Jobseeker's Allowance.

##Reduced rates
There are reduced rates for some [married women and widows](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/reducedrate/marriedwomen.htm "married women and widows"){:rel="external"} and if you have a separate, 'contracted out' pension scheme through your employer.

##Voluntary contributions

You can pay [voluntary National Insurance contributions](/voluntary-national-insurance-contributions "voluntary National Insurance contributions") to cover or avoid gaps in your National Insurance record. You may have gaps from times when you didn't pay contributions, eg you weren't working and not claiming benefits.

^There's a full list of [National Insurance rates](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/rates/nic.htm "National Insurance rates"){:rel="external"} on the HMRC website.^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
table.title: How much National Insurance you pay

table.body:
National Insurance contributions count towards the benefits in the table.

| Benefit | Class 1: employees | Class 2: self-employed |  Class 3: voluntary contributions | 
 - | - | - | -
Basic State Pension | Yes | Yes | Yes 
Additional State Pension | Yes | No | No 
Contribution-based Jobseeker's Allowance | Yes | No | No
Contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance | Yes | Yes | No
Maternity Allowance | Yes | Yes | No
Bereavement benefits | Yes | Yes | Yes  

Class 4 contributions paid by self-employed people with a profit over £7,605 don't count towards state benefits.
table.title: What National Insurance is for

table.body:
Your benefits could be affected if there are gaps in your National Insurance record. National Insurance credits help protect them.

You can get credits if you can't pay National Insurance contributions, for example, if:

- you can't work due to illness 
- you're caring for someone

Read more about [National Insurance credits](/boost-state-pension/national-insurance-credits-eligibility "about National Insurance credits") to see if you qualify and how to apply.

^If you're not working or getting credits you can also top up your National Insurance with [voluntary contributions.](/voluntary-national-insurance-contributions "voluntary contributions")^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Help if you're not working

table.body:
##Check your National Insurance record
You can apply to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to check your [National Insurance record](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/shortforms/form/NIStatement?dept-name=&sub-dept-name=&location=40&origin=http://www.hmrc.gov.uk "check your National Insurance record"){:rel="external"}.

HMRC will write to you after you applied and let you know what the next steps are.

[Contact HMRC if you live or work abroad](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/contactus/view.page?record=OLul3tPejl4 "Contact HMRC if you live or work abroad"){:rel="external"}

##If your circumstances change

If your address or name changes or you get married or enter a civil partnership you must [contact HMRC](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/shortforms/form/PAYENICoC?dept-name=PAYENI&sub-dept-name=COC&location=44&origin=http://www.hmrc.gov.uk "tell HMRC"){:rel="external"}

If you start or stop self-employment you need to to contact HMRC and let them know.

$C
**HMRC National Insurance line:**  
0845 915 4655  
Monday to Friday 8.30am to 5pm
$C

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Record check and change of circumstance
